com.hush.pgp
Class Key

java.lang.Object
  com.hush.pgp.Signable
      com.hush.pgp.Key
All Implemented Interfaces:
PgpConstants, java.io.Serializable
public class Key
extends Signable
implements java.io.Serializable

An object representing a PGP key. This it may be either a public key or a secret key. The only difference is that a public key will contain no secret key material.

See Also:
Serialized Form

Key

public Key(int version,
           long creationTimeSeconds,
           int publicKeyAlgorithm,
           int keySize,
           Key.KeyType type,
           java.security.SecureRandom random)
Constructor for generating a new key.

Parameters:
version - must be 4
creationTimeSeconds - the creation time for the key in seconds since 1970-01-01 00:00:00 UTC.
publicKeyAlgorithm - the type of public key to generate
keySize - the desired key length in bits
type - the key type and determines its use for example to encrypt data or to sign data
random - a source of entropy for key generation

addSubkey

public Key addSubkey(Key subkey)
Adds a subkey to the key. If a key with the same key ID already exists, the information is merged.

Parameters:
subkey - the subkey to add
Returns:
either the sub key, or the sub key with which it was merged

decryptSecretKey

public void decryptSecretKey(byte[] password)
                      throws DataFormatException,
                             UnrecoverableKeyException
Decrypts any secret key material associated with the key so that the secret key can be used for signing or decryption.

Parameters:
password - the password that will decrypt the key.
Throws:
DataFormatException
UnrecoverableKeyException

encryptSecretKeyMaterial

public void encryptSecretKeyMaterial(byte[] password,
                                     int symmetricAlgorithm,
                                     int s2kType,
                                     int s2kHashAlgorithm,
                                     int s2kCount,
                                     boolean checksumMod65536)
                              throws UnrecoverableKeyException
This method encrypts any existing secret key material with the password given. If the password is null, the secret key material will be left unencrypted. This method can be used to change or eliminate a password on an existing key.

Parameters:
password - the password or null for no password
symmetricAlgorithm - the algorithm to use for encryption, a constant from com.hush.pgp.PgpConstants
s2kType - the type of S2K conversion to use, a constant from com.hush.pgp.PgpConstants
s2kHashAlgorithm - the hash algorithm with which to process the password, a constant from com.hush.pgp.PgpConstants
s2kCount - the number of octets to process while converting the password
checksumMod65536 - if true, use MOD 65536 for the checksum on encrypted keys; uses SHA1 otherwise; does not apply to non-encrypted; setting to true will give PGP >= 6.5.8 compatibility.
Throws:
UnrecoverableKeyException

getCreationTime

getEncryptionKey

public Key getEncryptionKey()
Finds the most recent, valid, non-revoked encryption key and returns it, or null if one is not found. Subkeys are preferred over main keys.

If you want to use a key for encryption that is revoked or no longer valid, select it manually, not using this method.

This goes only by the algorithm type, not by the usage convention signature packet which may or may not exist.

This will not return keys for experimental algorithms such as Elliptic Curve or X9.42.

This will not verify any signatures. Those have to be checked separately. All self-signatures were probabaly verified when you retrieved the key from its key ring.

Returns:
the encryption key

public long getKeyExpirationTime()
Returns the key expiration in seconds since the creation time.

It returns zero if the key doesn't expire.

getVerifiedCertifications

public UserID[] getVerifiedCertifications(Key signer,
                                          long time)
                                   throws InvalidSignatureException
Returns all the certifications that are signed by this particular signer and valid for the specified time.

This method does not check for revocations.

Parameters:
signer - the signer of the certification
time - check for validity at this time in seconds since 1970-01-01 00:00:00; 0 to ignore
Throws:
InvalidSignatureException

public boolean hasUserID(java.lang.String userID)
Checks to see if this key has a user ID packet that matches the given user ID. This method does NOT verify that the self signature on the user ID is valid, so be sure to verify the self-certifications before you use it.

Parameters:
userID -
Returns:
true if the user ID is there

isExpired

public boolean isExpired(long time)
Checks to see if this key is expired. If this key's main key is considered to be expired, this key is considered to be expired as well. This method does not verify any signatures.

Parameters:
time - check for validity at this time in seconds since 1970-01-01 00:00:00

verifySelfSignatures

public void verifySelfSignatures()
                          throws MissingSelfSignatureException,
                                 InvalidSignatureException
This method verifies the self-signature this key, and all subkeys and user IDs.

If this method is called on a subkey, it just passes the method up to the parent key.

This method does NOT check to see if any keys or certifications have expired.

This method does NOT check to see if any keys or certifications have been revoked.

Throws:
MissingSelfSignatureException - if there are any unsigned subkeys or user ID's; or if a signature fails.
InvalidSignatureException

merge

public void merge(Key key)
This function is for use with two keys that have the same key ID. It merges all the information in the key passed as a parameter into the object upon which the method is called.

It will recursively merge all subkeys.

All signatures, user ID's, user attributes, and trust info, on the parameter key will be added to the object. This may result in duplicates.

Parameters:
key - the key to merge into this object
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the key ID's don't match

test

public void test(java.security.SecureRandom random)
Pair-wise consistency check conforming to FIPS140-2.

                 Key signer,
                 int signatureType,
                 long creationTime,
                 java.security.SecureRandom random)
          throws UnrecoverableKeyException
Description copied from class: Signable
Computes the signature and adds it to the signatures on this object. Set any flags on the signature you want before computing it.

signature - the signture to be added
